justification: "Researchers tend to study group cooperation in laboratory settings using stylized interactions known as economic games … The most commonly used of these economic games includes the Prisoner’s Dilemma (PD)…"
The text explains that "The most commonly used of these economic games includes … the Public Goods Game (PGG)" and that such games are used to study group cooperation.
In listing standard instruments, the article notes "The most commonly used of these economic games includes … the Dictator Game (DG)" for examining cooperative behaviour.
The same sentence reports that the Ultimatum Game (UG) is among the primary economic games "used to study group cooperation."
The authors add that "there are many other games used to study social decision-making (e.g., the Trust Game)," indicating this game as the instrument for assessing trust in cooperative contexts.
Later, the chapter states that researchers "measured how prosocial (vs. selfish) participants were using an index called Social Value Orientation."
